items.title: [INFO] How to use placeholders (reference only)
items.worker_notes: Reference only — not for copying.
items.text:
Templates may include placeholders in [SQUARE BRACKETS]. Replace them before saving.

Common placeholders:

[CLIENT] – client name or pronoun
[DATE] – date of contact
[LANDING / LOCATION] – wing/landing/unit
[UNIT / CASU] – CASU/healthcare/other unit
[OBSERVATIONS] – objective presentation (as recorded)
[DURATION] – e.g. “7 days”, “2 weeks”
[SEASON / HOLIDAY PERIOD] – e.g. “Christmas period”
[SUBSTANCES] – list as discussed

items.title: [GENERAL] Harm Reduction – Contact Note Block
items.worker_notes: General harm reduction discussion; adjust to the contact.
items.text: Harm reduction advice discussed focusing on vulnerability at this time of year, including missing family and emotional wellbeing. Discussion included the impact of illicit substance use on mental and physical health, reduced tolerance levels following periods of abstinence, withdrawal risks, overdose risks, BBV awareness, and risks associated with using illicit substances on top of prescribed medication. Client was also advised of current drug trends within the establishment and the increased risks posed by unknown or contaminated substances.

No reports that [CLIENT] is involved and [CLIENT] stated he has no involvement and has not taken anything.

items.title: [GENERAL] Robust Harm Reduction – Summary (Audit-Friendly)
items.worker_notes: A strong ‘robust HR’ paragraph for audits.
items.text: Robust harm reduction given around tolerance levels, poly drug use, sharing drug paraphernalia, overdose risks, blood borne viruses, not using alone, impact of prescribed medication on illicit drug use and increased overdose risks. Risks of serious harm and possible death explained and advice given.

items.title: [TRENDS] Current Drug Trends in Establishment
items.worker_notes: Use when you specifically mention current trends (benzos, NPS/psychoactives, hooch, subutex etc.).
items.text: Thoroughly discussed harm reduction advice around the risks associated with illicit substance use, impacts to mental and physical health, reduced tolerance levels, withdrawal risks, risk of overdose, poly-drug use, and using on top of prescribed medication. Also advised of the risks associated with current drug trends within the establishment such as benzodiazepine, psychoactive substances, prison hooch and subutex.

items.title: [SUBSTANCES] Named Substances Discussed (e.g. Xanax / Pregabalin / NPS)
items.worker_notes:
Use when naming specific substances discussed.

items.text: Harm reduction advice discussed around the risks associated with specific substances including [SUBSTANCES – e.g. Xanax, pregabalin, psychoactive substances (NPS)] and other prescription medications. Discussed increased risks when using these substances alongside alcohol or other illicit drugs.

items.title: [POLY-USE] Mixing Substances (incl. Alcohol + Cocaine)
items.worker_notes: Use when focusing on mixing substances, especially alcohol + cocaine (cocaethylene).
items.text: Discussed harm reduction advice around poly drug use and the dangers of mixing stimulants with depressants. Advised not to use alcohol with cocaine due to formation of cocaethylene and increased risk of liver damage. Risks explained and advice given.

items.title: [SAFER USE] Pressure to Use / Sharing Equipment
items.worker_notes: Use when addressing coercion, bullying, pressured use, and sharing works.
items.text: Discussed harm reduction advice including not feeling pressured into using or sharing drugs or equipment, including tourniquets. Promoted honest discussion around use to ensure risks are reduced as they occur.

items.title: [PRACTICE] Honest Discussion Promoted
items.worker_notes: Short add-on line for Portal notes.
items.text: An honest discussion around substance use was promoted to help reduce risk and encourage engagement.

items.title: [CHECKLIST] Quick Safer-Use Checklist (Bullets)
items.worker_notes: Fast bullet list for Portal notes.
items.text:
Start with a small amount (e.g. a dab or half a pill).

Don’t be afraid of seeking help and being honest about what you have taken.

Avoid mixing drugs, especially with alcohol. Remember Methadone (even if prescribed) is a drug and will increase overdose risks if used with illicit drugs.

Tell someone you are with what you have taken.

Try and buy from a trusted source.

Try to avoid injecting as getting the right amount is difficult for first time users and it carries greater risks.

Try to use with trusted friends in a safe environment, especially if it’s your first time.

Look after friends: if unconscious, place in recovery position and seek emergency support. Administer Naloxone if available.

items.title: [INJECTING] Basic (Smoke Not Inject)
items.worker_notes: Short injecting reduction block.
items.text: Smoke not inject. If injecting, only use a small amount. Don’t share cookers or needles with anyone else. Risk of BBVs is heightened if sharing.

items.title: [INJECTING] Clean Works, Vein Damage, DVT
items.worker_notes: Use when documenting needle re-use, vein damage, infections, and DVT risks.
items.text: Discussed importance of using clean ‘works’, particularly using a needle only once where possible to avoid barbing of the tips and the subsequent vein damage which can lead to abscesses, infections, collapsed veins and DVTs.

items.title: [INJECTING] Tourniquet + Groin Injecting Risks (Femoral artery/nerve)
items.worker_notes: Use when documenting higher-risk injecting harm reduction.
items.text: If using a tourniquet, advised to release the tourniquet before pushing the plunger to avoid risk of loss of limb if an overdose occurs and the person is alone. Advised to rotate sites. Discussed groin injecting risks including keeping the area clean, checking for abscesses, risk of hitting the femoral artery (may require hospitalisation) and risk of damaging the femoral nerve which controls leg and muscle movement and can result in serious mobility problems or paralysis.

items.title: [ALCOHOL] Harm Reduction Block
items.worker_notes: Use when alcohol is relevant to the client’s risks/triggers.
items.text:
Alcohol – drink a lower ABV where possible and a smaller amount.

Don’t drink on an empty stomach.

Don’t mix spirits, lagers and beers as it makes it harder to count units.

Don’t exceed 14 units in a week if possible (Government Guidelines).

Be aware alcohol may be a trigger for other drugs (cocaine).

items.title: [OVERDOSE] Tolerance + Not Using Alone
items.worker_notes: Use when you’ve discussed overdose risk and basic safety steps.
items.text: Overdose risks discussed. Tolerance levels may be lower following periods of reduced or no illicit use, so advised to use only a small amount at a time. Advised not to use alone and to use with others where possible.

items.title: [OVERDOSE] Response (Recovery Position, CPR, Ambulance)
items.worker_notes: Use when you’ve covered recognising overdose and what to do.
items.text: Discussed how to identify signs of depressant overdose and stimulant overdose. Discussed recovery position and chest compressions until ambulance arrives. Discussed how to call an ambulance, what to say, staying with the person until help arrives, and informing ambulance crew what substances have been taken.

items.title: [NALOXONE] Full Training (Injectable + Nasal)
items.worker_notes: Use when you deliver or document Naloxone training and the client’s understanding.
items.text: Naloxone training given and advised, including how Naloxone works, how to recognise an opioid overdose, when and how Naloxone would be beneficial, and how/where to administer. Discussed safe disposal routes of used kits, recovery position and calling an ambulance. Discussed both injectable and nasal administration. Client engaged well and demonstrated understanding.

items.title: [NALOXONE] Basic Awareness
items.worker_notes: Shorter block when you only cover basics.
items.text: Basic Naloxone use discussed and advised including when and how Naloxone would be beneficial, awareness of how to administer, recovery position and emergency response.

items.title: [NALOXONE] Agreement to Take on Release / Pre-Release Training
items.worker_notes: Use when the client agrees to take Naloxone on release.
items.text: Agreed client will take Naloxone on release and complete 1-1 training pre-release where required. Client demonstrated understanding of overdose signs and the positives of having Naloxone.

items.text: [CLIENT] advised of upcoming community appointment following release. Explained that appointment details and paperwork will be available on the day of release.

items.title: [BBV] Awareness, Transmission, Reducing Risk
items.worker_notes: Use when BBVs were covered as part of harm reduction.
items.text: BBV discussion held regarding how BBVs are transmitted and how to reduce risks of contamination. Advised not to share any drug paraphernalia; any shared item can carry BBVs and it is not limited to needles. Testing, support and treatment options discussed and client advised to contact DART for further information or support. Encouraged ongoing discussions around BBVs to raise awareness and reduce stigma.

items.title: [HEALTH] Immune System / Illness Risk
items.worker_notes: Standalone health-focused harm reduction block.
items.text: Discussed how illicit substance use can weaken the immune system and increase the risk of illness, including Covid and flu. Advised on basic hygiene measures to reduce risk of infection.

items.title: [HEALTH] Infection / Illness Risks (COVID/Flu)
items.worker_notes: Use when you include illness risks and hygiene advice.
items.text: Discussion held around illicit substance use weakening immune system and increasing risks of Covid, flu and other illnesses. Advised to reduce risks of disease and illness: use clean surfaces, wash hands before and after, do not share equipment, attempt to keep area sterile and sanitise regularly.

items.title: [HOOCH] Health Risks Block
items.worker_notes: Use when hooch is relevant.
items.text:
Hooch health risks discussed including BBV risks and long-term organ damage. Advised negative impact on health, wellbeing and time in custody. Disease and illness linked to hooch discussed and encouraged abstinence while in custody. Honest discussions around use to continue to ensure risks are reduced as they occur.

Other side effects discussed may include damage to optic nerves, loss of sight/impaired vision, internal bleeding, liver damage, overdose, stroke, botulism poisoning (fatal), and risk of death.

items.title: [MEDS] Prescription Medication – Harm Reduction
items.worker_notes: Use when discussing pregabalin/benzos/other meds or unknown substances.
items.text: Harm around prescription medications discussed. Warned about deaths in the community from prescription medications used alongside other substances and the risks around using unknown substances. Open discussions promoted and encouraged safer use where appropriate. Long-term impact on health and wellbeing discussed and confirmed to be understood. Client advised to alert staff or use services (in custody and on release) if suspected overdose or if medical support is required.

items.title: [WELLBEING] Debt / Bullying / Regime Impacts
items.worker_notes: Use when you discuss prison-specific consequences.
items.text: Discussed impacts of illicit substance use on overall wellbeing including risk of debt, bullying/exploitation, negative impact on prison regime and associated consequences. Client participated well and demonstrated understanding.

items.title: [RISK CHECK] No Self-Harm/Suicide Disclosed
items.worker_notes: Quick line to add to many Portal notes.
items.text: No thoughts of self-harm or suicide disclosed.

items.title: [BBV] Hep B / Hep C Status (If Provided)

items.text: Client stated he has had his Hep B course of injections and was tested for Hep C.
